stream_context.summary: Kaze spends the stream hunting two critical bugs (a frame-perfect landing crash and a memory-overflow on level load) while waiting for Biobak’s new "Dino Dino Domain" assets, then imports and cleans up the reworked level, fixes visual/render-mode issues, and brainstorms design tweaks (save block, disco-ball star, tutorials).

development_findings.summary: Pressing A one frame before landing (especially after a long-jump) crashes on real hardware and Project64; disabling Mario’s animation updates prevents the crash, implying a bad animation pointer or double switch in a single frame.
development_findings.quote: "Why does my game not crash anymore? There is no way it was the animations, right? It was the animations!"

development_findings.summary: The new Dino Dino Domain import exceeded RAM by ~1 KB; Kaze traced the failure to pool allocation, removed an unused leaf-boat object and a duplicate Luigi texture, and enabled Bleed/Inline export to reclaim memory.
development_findings.quote: "We were using literally one kilobyte of memory too much. One not even full texture."

development_findings.summary: Plan to place the star inside the nightclub disco ball: Mario grabs the pole, ball falls, shatters, lights and music die, Shy Guys stop dancing, giving immediate feedback that the player ‘stole the party’.
development_findings.quote: "Imagine the star is inside the disco ball and as soon as you steal it, the entire room goes dark."

development_findings.summary: Added a visible ‘save block’ near level exits even though the game autosaves; purely psychological, so players feel secure before quitting.
development_findings.quote: "The game saves automatically. This is about psychology."

development_findings.summary: Implemented a new vine‐jump helper: Mario auto-rotates toward the next vine and a single A-press always latches, reducing camera alignment frustration.
Will restore the Act 1 wall-kick tutorial (bunnies + Yoshi coin) and consider adding multiple cues so absolute newcomers learn the move.
Fast64’s built-in texture scroll runs at 30 FPS; Kaze will code a custom scroll routine to keep it 60 FPS.
Strict compile flags now yield zero warnings; any new warnings will be treated as bugs.
development_findings.quote: "I fixed every single compile warning in my game. Zero warnings, look at this."

development_findings.summary: Dual-texture brick material needed two-cycle mode; Kaze fixed render mode and environment alpha issues that caused flicker on hardware.
Performance snapshot: worst-case camera in the new layout is ~22.5 FPS with AA; Kaze expects occlusion planes and engine upgrades to bring it back to 30 FPS.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shows visible frustration and amusement while single-stepping MIPS assembly; enjoys the detective work despite calling it "schizo-rambling".
He reinstalled Windows 11 recently, rebuilding his toolchain, and lost time to GIMP freezes and NVIDIA/ShadowPlay issues.
context_findings.quote: "Somehow I can't do anything except talk. Task manager. CPU 100%."

context_findings.summary: Annoyed by viewers insisting his collaborator’s narration is an AI voice, he rails against ‘AI investigations’.
context_findings.quote: "It's literally not even an AI voice, that is just Joshua's voice."

context_findings.summary: Mentions pet pleco babies hatching—brief personal aside showing life outside dev.
Design philosophy: players claim they want to think, but actually prefer clear guidance (yellow paint/sidebar tutorials).
context_findings.quote: "People don't want to think. People want to think that they want to think."

biobak.summary: Delivered a massive Dino Dino Domain rework: lower-poly water, new mountains, mossy bricks, disco redesign, Yoshi stomach remodel, vegetation, decorative pillars, lighting passes, and a detailed changelog.
biobak.quote: "Alright, we're gonna get a big DinoDino domain rework today."

biobak.summary: Some changes pushed memory over the limit and introduced triple-overdraw hotspots; Kaze will add occlusion planes and optimise.

zeina.summary: Currently creating neon sign assets for Course 15’s retro section, using the same combiner tricks planned for Dino Dino Domain’s nightclub.

key_stories.title: The Frame-Perfect Landing Crash
key_stories.summary: A mysterious crash occurs when A is pressed the frame before Mario lands. Kaze debugs live in MIPS assembly, discovering the crash vanishes if animations are disabled.
key_stories.challenge: Game hard-crashes from a single frame input, jeopardising BLJs and general stability.
key_stories.process: Used Nemu64 debugger, inspected registers, traced through landing and animation code, toggled animation pointer writes.
key_stories.outcome: Isolated to animation switching; root cause still pending but direction set.
key_stories.key_quote: "It is very easy to fix by just removing the one frame input buffer, which is concerning."

key_stories.title: One-Kilobyte Memory Overflow
key_stories.summary: Importing Biobak’s new level crashes on load. Kaze traces it to the memory pool being short by ~1 KB.
key_stories.challenge: Level would not load on real hardware; allocator returned NULL.
key_stories.process: Stepped through pool allocation, compared free space, removed unused assets (leaf boat, duplicate texture) and rebuilt with Bleed/Inline.
key_stories.outcome: Level boots successfully; highlights razor-thin RAM margins on N64.

key_stories.title: Stealing the Disco Star
key_stories.summary: Kaze envisions a set-piece where the player literally turns off the party.
key_stories.challenge: Create memorable feedback for collecting the star in the nightclub.
key_stories.process: Conceptual brainstorm: place star inside disco ball, have pole snap, ball shatter, room darken, Shy Guys stop.
key_stories.outcome: Design note added to to-do list; will be prototyped.
key_stories.key_quote: "We are spreading suffering and misery across our enemies."

open_questions.context: Crash disappears when animations disabled, but root cause and permanent solution not implemented.

open_questions.context: Level barely fits after quick asset removals; future additions risk new overflows.
